instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V8_S4: What is PP1V8_S4? PP1V8_S4 is a 1.8v power rail when the machine is in an S4, suspend to disk state. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message:
Hello. I got another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not liquid damaged but just randomly stopped turning on. It was taking 20v 0.03a when I first plugged it in and I found that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was .230v and .032 in diode mode. I checked for the same value on all big coils and found that L8050 was also .032 in diode. I replaced <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> and PPBUS was no longer shorted anymore but it still will not turn on. Now I have 20v 0.04a and seem to have all S5 voltages but nothing on any S4. I can't seem to find anymore shorts so not sure where to look next. Here are some voltages I took.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
PPVCCPRIMCORE_SUS_PCH - 1v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message:
PCH got an overvoltage on PPVCCPRIMCORE_SUS_PCH power rail; it could be dead now.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If present, check for pulse at any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message: Ok so I am actually missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> but I have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>. I triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> does drop but <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> does not. Should I replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> or is this a CPU issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> must stay high, if charger is connected.
Didn't chek the other mentioned signals for pulse???

Also check <SIGNAL>PM_RSMTST_L</SIGNAL> if steady high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMTST_L</SIGNAL> is steady 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v but does drop when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is steady 3.3v
All other <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals are 0v and do not react at all when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message:
Looks like dead PCH, sorry...

You can still check the RTC signals, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power. PPBUS shorted
threads.message: Damn that's what I thought. I checked <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> are both steady 3.4v and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is 2.8v. Thanks.
